image: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Maples_leaves_and_lantern.jpg/1280px-Maples_leaves_and_lantern.jpg
https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Maples_leaves_and_lantern.jpg/1280px-Maples_leaves_and_lantern.jpg

origin: Mediterranean region
size: Upright forms reach between 1.2–1.8 meters (4–6 ft) tall. Leaves are 2–4 cm long.
lightRequirements: At least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun daily.
soilNeeds: Well-drained, loamy, slightly acidic soil with a pH between 6.0 and 7.0.
waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Prefers soil to dry out between waterings.
flowerInfo: Can be purple, white, pink, or blue. Flowers in spring and summer in temperate climates.
barkTrunk: Woody
rootType: Fibrous root system.
pruningNeeds: Regular pruning to maintain a bushy shape. Prune annually before new growth begins in spring. Do not prune more than one-third of the plant at a time.
pestsAndDiseases: Pest-resistant. Susceptible to root rot in waterlogged conditions. Good air circulation is important to prevent foliar diseases.
notes: Now considered a synonym for *Salvia rosmarinus*. Can live for up to 35 years. Used for culinary purposes, fragrance, and has cultural significance (symbol of remembrance).

origin: Mediterranean basin
size: Up to 1 to 2 meters (3.5 to 6.5 ft) tall. Leaves are 2–6 centimeters long.
lightRequirements: Full sun, at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily.
soilNeeds: Well-drained, light, sandy, or gravelly soils. Prefers slightly alkaline pH (6.5-7.5).
waterNeeds: Low water consumption. Drought-tolerant. Water young plants regularly, established plants only when the top 2 inches of soil are dry.
flowerInfo: Typically purple, produced on spikes at the top of slender, leafless stems.
pestsAndDiseases: Prune annually after flowering, cutting back about one-third into the foliage.
plantLocation: Generally low. Can deter pests like flies, fleas, aphids, and whiteflies. Susceptible to root rot in wet soils.
notes: Mediterranean basin (native).
image: Previously known as `Lavandula officinalis`. Flowers and leaves are used in herbal medicine. Commercially, it is used to produce lavender essential oil. Considered a low flammability plant.

origin: Central and eastern Mexico
shape: Herbaceous perennial plant with numerous erect stems
size: often arching at their tips.
growthRate: Up to 1.3 m (4.3 ft) high and 2 m (6.6 ft) wide. Leaves are linear-lanceolate.
landscapeUses: Leaves are soft mid-green with whitish, hairy undersides. Velvety blue or purple inflorescences.
lightRequirements: Ornamental plant. Attracts butterflies, bees, and hummingbirds.
soilNeeds: Full sun, at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily.
waterNeeds: Rich, evenly moist, and well-drained soil. Can adapt to clays or sands.
sunsetZone: Drought-tolerant once established but performs best with consistent moisture. Water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings.
tolerances: Not frost-hardy, but can withstand light frosts.
flowerInfo: Drought-tolerant.
fruitInfo: Typically white, emerging from colored bracts (velvety blue or purple).
plantLocation: Prune in early spring, cutting plants back nearly to the ground after the last frost. Light trimming can be done in summer to maintain shape.
notes: Generally resistant. Can be susceptible to whiteflies, aphids, mealybugs, spider mites, rust, powdery mildew, stem rot, and fungal leaf spot, especially with excessive irrigation.
image: Native to subtropical and tropical conifer forests in central and eastern Mexico.

origin: Western North America
shape: Broad and rounded crown in open areas, narrow in young trees in closed stands, irregularly broad in old trees.
size: Typically 9–25 meters (30–82 feet) tall and 0.3–1.4 meters (1–4.5 feet) in diameter. Can exceed 36 meters (118 feet) in height.
growthRate: Sprout growth averages about 2 feet per year for the first 10 years.
texture: Leaves are deeply lobed. Bark is thin and smooth when young, becoming thick, ridged, plate-like, and blackish with age.
landscapeUses: Ornamental tree in native plant, drought-tolerant, water-conserving, and habitat gardens.
lightRequirements: Full sun. Less shade tolerant than ponderosa pine.
soilNeeds: Deep, fertile loam. Tolerates heavier clay soils. Prefers well-drained soils of medium to coarse texture. Requires acidic soils.
waterNeeds: Medium water needs. Drought-tolerant. Young trees require regular watering.
flowerInfo: Monoecious, with male flowers in catkins and females in leaf axils, blooming late in spring.
fruitInfo: Acorns are relatively large, 2.5–4 centimeters (1–1.5 inches) long and 1.5–1.8 centimeters (0.5–0.75 inches) wide.
barkTrunk: Bark is thin and smooth when young, becoming thick, ridged, plate-like, and blackish with age.
rootType: Deep taproot.
notes: found in mixed evergreen forests
image: oak woodlands

commonName: Strawberry tree, madrone, Irish strawberry tree, cane apple
origin: Mediterranean Basin and Western Europe
size: 4–7 meters (13–23 ft) tall, rarely up to 15 meters (50 ft).
texture: Leaves are green and glossy. Fruit has a rough surface. Bark is rough and shredding red-brown.
landscapeUses: Ornamental. Ecological design as a pioneer plant for restoring degraded ecosystems.
lightRequirements: Full sun for best flowering and fruiting, can tolerate light shade.
soilNeeds: Well-draining loamy soil, but can tolerate sandy, loamy, or rocky soils. Prefers slightly acidic to neutral pH (around 6.5).
waterNeeds: Fairly drought-resistant. Water regularly during dry spells until established.
flowerInfo: White, bell-shaped flowers bloom in autumn.
fruitInfo: Red, spherical berry, 7–20 mm in diameter, with a rough surface. Edible.
barkTrunk: Rough, shredding red-brown bark.
pruningNeeds: Minimal pruning is generally needed. Lightly thin and shape the tree after fruiting.
pestsAndDiseases: May be susceptible to aphids, arbutus leaf spot, and honey fungus.
plantLocation: Native to the Mediterranean Basin and Western Europe.
notes: National tree of Italy. The name "unedo" is attributed to Pliny the Elder. Berries are used for jam, marmalades, yogurt, and alcoholic beverages. Leaves have been used in traditional medicine. Wood is used for firewood and pipes. Mentioned in Ovid's Metamorphoses. Part of the Coat of Arms of Madrid. Does not transplant well.
image: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Arbutus_unedo_habitus.jpg

commonName: Blue oak, mountain oak, iron oak
origin: California
size: Generally 6–20 meters (20–66 feet) tall, with a trunk 36–60 centimeters (1–2 ft) in diameter.
texture: Leaves are tough and leathery. Bark is light gray with many medium-sized dark cracks.
landscapeUses: Provides food and shelter for wildlife.
lightRequirements: Full sun, but can tolerate part shade.
soilNeeds: Prefers acidic, well-drained soils and is tolerant of various soil types as long as drainage is sufficient. Particularly well-suited to dry, rocky soils.
waterNeeds: Highly drought-tolerant once established. Requires minimal summer watering, approximately once a month.
flowerInfo: Drought-tolerant.
barkTrunk: Acorns are 2–3 cm long with a moderately sweet kernel, maturing in 6–7 months.
rootType: Light gray with many medium-sized dark cracks.
pruningNeeds: Deep taproot.
pestsAndDiseases: Young trees can be pruned to achieve a desired shape. For mature trees, light pruning in winter is recommended. Heavy pruning should be avoided.
plantLocation: Common issues include crown rot, mistletoe, armillaria, brown rot, caterpillars, insect galls, California oak moth, and gall wasp.
notes: Endemic to California
image: common in the Coast Ranges and the foothills of the Sierra Nevada.

origin: Hybrid origin, possibly involving *Arctostaphylos stanfordiana*, *A. densiflora*, and potentially other species like *Arctostaphylos bakeri* and *A. manzanita*.
size: evergreen mounding shrub.
soilNeeds: shiny green leaves.
sunsetZone: Full sun to light shade.
fruitInfo: 0-10 degrees Fahrenheit.
barkTrunk: Tolerant of various soils, occasional summer watering, and pruning.
rootType: Showy clusters of small white flowers tinged with light pink from late winter into spring.
pruningNeeds: Small, brick-red berries that mature in the summer and can persist into winter.
notes: Tolerant of pruning. Can be kept smaller with pruning.

origin: Discovered at Powis Castle in Wales. Hybrid between *Artemisia absinthium* and *Artemisia arborescens*.
size: low
density: About 60-90 cm (2-3 ft) in height and spreading 1.5-2 meters (4-6 ft) wide if not contained.
lightRequirements: Finely dissected, soft, silvery-gray-green, velvet-lacy textured leaves.
soilNeeds: Borders, rock gardens, low-maintenance gardens, Mediterranean gardens, dry gardens, mixed borders and beds with low water requirements, containers. Provides excellent contrast with other flowering perennials and ornamental grasses.
waterNeeds: Full sun. Partial shade is acceptable in very hot climates but can reduce compactness.
sunsetZone: Well-drained soils, even poor or sandy types. Susceptible to root rot in moist or waterlogged conditions.
fruitInfo: Heat and drought tolerant. Very cold hardy.
barkTrunk: Generally inconspicuous, pale yellow, appear in summer. Often removed to maintain plant's shape.
notes: Regular pruning to maintain ornamental value, prevent woodiness, and promote density. Main pruning in late winter or early spring (cut stems about 15 cm from ground). Light summer pruning to contain shape.

commonName: California laurel, California bay, Oregon myrtle, pepperwood, spicebush, cinnamon bush, peppernut tree, headache tree, mountain laurel, balm of heaven
origin: Native to California and Oregon.
size: Up to 30 meters (98 feet) tall with a trunk up to 90 centimeters (35 inches) in diameter. Typically 30 to 75 feet tall and wide.
texture: Leaves are fragrant, smooth-edged, and lance-shaped. Bark and leaves have a pungent camphor-like scent.
landscapeUses: Grown as an ornamental tree, hedge, or windbreak. Ecological design as a pioneer plant for restoring degraded ecosystems.
lightRequirements: Full sun to partial or even full shade.
soilNeeds: Well-draining, fertile soils with a slightly acidic to neutral pH. Can tolerate various soil types, including loamy, sandy, or clay soils. Adaptable to serpentine soils. Good drainage is crucial.
waterNeeds: Water regularly, allowing the soil to dry out partially between waterings. Can tolerate dry conditions, but performs best with consistent moisture. Reduce watering in winter.
flowerInfo: Small, yellow or yellowish-green flowers, produced in small umbels.
fruitInfo: Round, green berry that ripens to purple, known as "California bay nut." Edible flesh and inner kernel.
rootType: Bark and leaves have a pungent camphor-like scent.
pruningNeeds: Pruning helps maintain the tree's shape and health. Done in late winter or early spring. Remove dead or diseased branches and thin out crowded areas. Avoid heavy pruning if training as a large shrub.
pestsAndDiseases: Host for *Phytophthora ramorum*, the pathogen causing sudden oak death.
plantLocation: Southwest Oregon and California, extending south to San Diego County, and in the western foothills of the Sierra Nevada mountains. Altitudes from sea level up to 1,600 meters (5,200 feet). Primarily inhabits redwood forests, California mixed woods, yellow pine forests, and oak woodlands.
notes: Sole species in the genus *Umbellularia*. Leaves are pungent and have a stronger fragrance than those of true bay (Laurus nobilis), hence used as a substitute. Traditionally used for medicinal purposes by Native Americans. Wood is used for cabinetry and other woodworking. Pollen is a significant allergen.
image: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Umbellularia_californica_01.JPG

commonName: Blue passionflower, bluecrown passionflower, common passion flower
origin: South America
size: deciduous or semi-evergreen tendril-bearing vine.
growthRate: Can grow to 10 meters (33 ft) or more, up to 25 meters (82 ft) high with supporting trees.
landscapeUses: Leaves are palmately lobed, typically with five lobes.
lightRequirements: Widely cultivated as a wall-climber or groundcover.
soilNeeds: Full sun to partial shade. Requires at least four to six hours of direct sunlight daily.
waterNeeds: Moist but well-drained, loose soil that is rich in organic matter. Soil pH can range from 6.1 to 7.5 (neutral to acidic).
sunsetZone: Water regularly during dry weather, especially during the growing season, keeping the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Deep watering infrequently. Reduce watering in winter.
flowerInfo: Can survive winter temperatures as low as −10 °C (14 °F).
fruitInfo: Fragrant, complex and striking, about 10 cm (4 inches) in diameter. Five sepals and five petals (whitish), with a prominent corona of blue or violet filaments, five greenish-yellow stamens and three purple stigmas. Usually open at night, present from summer to early autumn.
barkTrunk: Ovoid orange fruit, up to 6 cm (2 inches) across. Edible, but often bland or unpleasant flavor. Oval orange-yellow berry, 6 cm (2+1⁄4 in) long by 4 cm (1+1⁄2 in) in diameter, containing numerous seeds.
pruningNeeds: Prune in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Helps to control size and shape, remove dead or damaged growth, and encourage new growth for flowering. Overgrown plants can be renovated by cutting stems back to 30-60cm (1-2ft) from the base, every few years.
pestsAndDiseases: Whiteflies, spider mites, and scale. Fungal diseases if poor air circulation.
notes: National flower of Paraguay. Intricate structure associated with Christian symbolism. Sometimes used as a rootstock for grafting *P. edulis*. Medicinal properties, used by Toba and Maka peoples. Has gained the Royal Horticultural Society's Award of Garden Merit.
image: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Passiflora_caerulea_flower.jpg

commonName: Confederate jasmine, star jasmine, Confederate jessamine, Chinese star jessamine
origin: Eastern and southeastern Asia, including Japan, Korea, southern China, and Vietnam.
size: woody
growthRate: perennial vine. Can be grown as a climbing vine
landscapeUses: Can grow up to 20 feet tall (as a vine). Moderate growth rate, can reach 18 to 20 feet tall with support.
waterNeeds: Shiny, oval, dark green leaves.
sunsetZone: Vine, sprawling shrub, or ground cover.
usdaZone: Full sun to partial shade. At least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal flowering. Afternoon shade in hotter climates.
hardyTo: Fertile, well-drained soil. Tolerates average soils. Slightly acidic to neutral pH (around 6.0–7.5).
tolerances: Water deeply and regularly during the first growing season. Once established, tolerates dry spells and is considered drought-tolerant. Water when the top 1-2 inches of soil feel dry.
rootType: Drought-tolerant.
pruningNeeds: Clusters of sweetly fragrant, starry, creamy white flowers in late spring, with sporadic blooming throughout the summer. Attractive to bees.
image: Prune in early spring.

origin: Cultivar of *Ligustrum japonicum*, which is native to central and southern Japan and Korea.
size: dense
density: Typically reaches up to 9 feet tall, but often smaller.
lightRequirements: Thick, rounded, waxy, glossy dark green leaves.
soilNeeds: Hedges, can be trained into various shapes.
waterNeeds: Sun or light shade.
sunsetZone: (Not specified)
flowerInfo: Below 15 degrees Fahrenheit.
barkTrunk: Fragrant white flowers that attract bees, blooming in late spring to early summer.
rootType: Blue-black berries that follow the flowers, ripening in early winter. Food source for birds.
image: Waxleaf Privet" can also refer to other species like *Ligustrum lucidum* and *Ligustrum quihoui*.

origin: Most of China, excluding the far northeast.
shape: Vigorous shrub with arching branches and lanceolate leaves.
size: Up to 5 meters (16 ft) in height.
landscapeUses: Ornamental plant. Nectar source for many butterfly species.
lightRequirements: Full sun, at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily.
soilNeeds: Well-drained soil. Can tolerate poor soil, but performs best in moderately fertile, loamy soil.
waterNeeds: Water freely when actively growing, sparingly otherwise. Drought-tolerant once established.
flowerInfo: Honey-scented flowers, typically lilac to purple or occasionally white, produced in terminal panicles.
pruningNeeds: Essential to maintain shape, encourage new growth, and promote abundant flowering. Prune in early spring (buds swelling, April/May). Deadhead spent flower spikes to encourage new blooms and prevent self-seeding.
plantLocation: Native to most of China, excluding the far northeast. Naturalized in Australia and many European cities.
notes: Invasive species in several temperate regions (UK, Ireland, New Zealand). Invasiveness debated in US. Does not provide food for butterfly larvae.

origin: Cultivar of *Berberis thunbergii*, which is native to Japan.
size: deciduous shrub.
growthRate: Up to 1 meter (3 feet 3 inches) tall and 2.5 meters (8 feet 2 inches) wide.
lightRequirements: Leaves are deep rose-red, mottled with tones of white and pink. Deeply grooved, brown, spiny branches.
soilNeeds: Planted in beds, borders, or used as a screen or hedge.
waterNeeds: Full sun.
sunsetZone: (Not specified)
flowerInfo: Below 15 degrees Fahrenheit.
barkTrunk: Pale yellow flowers, 5–8 mm in diameter, appear in late spring to early summer in drooping clusters.
rootType: Glossy, bright red to orange-red, ovoid berries that are 7–10 mm long.
pruningNeeds: Deeply grooved, brown, spiny branches.
image: (Not specified)

commonName: Trumpet vine, yellow trumpet vine, trumpet creeper, cow-itch vine, hummingbird vine
origin: Eastern North America
size: deciduous woody vine.
growthRate: Can grow up to 10 meters (33 feet) long. Can grow 25-40 feet tall and 4-10 feet wide.
lightRequirements: Leaves are emerald green when new, maturing to a shiny dark green. Bark is tan and shreds easily.
soilNeeds: Attracts Ruby-throated Hummingbirds, bees, and butterflies. Useful for erosion control.
waterNeeds: Full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. Can tolerate partial shade, but flowering will be reduced.
sunsetZone: Adaptable to various soil types, including clay, sand, and poor soils, but prefers well-draining, moderately fertile, and moist soil.
usdaZone: Water regularly during establishment. Drought-tolerant once mature, but performs better if watered during dry spells.
fruitInfo: Showy, trumpet-shaped flowers, typically orange to reddish-orange and occasionally yellow. 2-3 inches long. Bloom from June through September.
barkTrunk: Long seed capsule, splits to disperse thin, brown, paper-like seeds.
rootType: Tan and shreds easily.
pruningNeeds: Aerial rootlets and twining stems (for climbing).
pestsAndDiseases: Prune hard in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Helps control size and shape and encourages more blooms.
notes: Native to eastern North America. Naturalized in other regions, including parts of the western United States, Europe, and Latin America.
image: Can be an aggressive colonizer. Foliage can cause skin redness and itching in some people. Slightly toxic if ingested. Genus name "Campsis" from Greek for "bent." Species epithet "radicans" is Latin for "producing roots.

origin: Western North America, from British Columbia through California (including the Sierra Nevada) into Baja California.
size: Fronds typically 1 to 3 meters in length. Can grow as high as seven feet.
texture: Bipinnately compound fronds with a leathery texture. chain-like sori. Ornament for gardens and habitat restoration projects.
lightRequirements: Moist, adequate soil drainage. Acidic or neutral soil.
soilNeeds: Requires moisture. Can tolerate extended periods without irrigation by tapping into latent soil moisture.
hardyTo: (Ferns do not have flowers or fruit. Reproduces via spores, sori arranged in chain-like pattern.)
flowerInfo: Dense mass of fibrous roots.
fruitInfo: (Not specified)
barkTrunk: Natural threats include soil erosion and competition from invasive species.
rootType: Native to western North America. Found in moist wooded habitats, coniferous forests, canyons, foothills, springs, streambeds.
pruningNeeds: Considered the most spectacular of California's native ferns. Used by native tribes for basket making and medicinal purposes. Received the Royal Horticultural Society's Award of Garden Merit.

origin: Western North America, from southeastern Alaska to southern California, and extending inland to southeastern British Columbia, northern Idaho, and western Montana. Disjunctive populations in northern British Columbia, the Black Hills in South Dakota, and Guadalupe Island off Baja California, Mexico.
shape: Evergreen perennial fern. Fronds grow in a tight clump
size: spreading radially from a round base.
growthRate: Fronds grow 50 to 180 cm (nearly 6 feet) tall.
landscapeUses: Bipinnately compound fronds with a leathery texture. chain-like sori. Pinnae have serrated edges with bristly tips.
soilNeeds: Understory of moist coniferous woodlands. (Prefers shade).
waterNeeds: Well-drained acidic soil with rich humus and small stones.
sunsetZone: Requires consistent moisture and cool weather. Resilient to occasional droughts, can be drought-tolerant once established.
tolerances: Tolerates extended periods without irrigation. Drought-tolerant once established. Deer-resistant.
flowerInfo: (Ferns do not have flowers or fruit. Reproduces via spores, sori are round, in two rows on either side of the midrib of each pinna.)
barkTrunk: Dense mass of fibrous roots.
rootType: (Not specified)
pruningNeeds: Natural threats include soil erosion and competition from invasive species.
pestsAndDiseases: Forests areas along the Pacific coast. Understory of moist coniferous woodlands at low elevations.
plantLocation: One of the most abundant ferns in forested areas along the Pacific coast. Individual fronds live for 1.5 to 2.5 years. Difficult to cultivate in eastern North America. Used by Native American/First Nations peoples for pain relief, counteracting nettle rashes, food (roasted rhizomes), and lining fire pits. Received the Royal Horticultural Society's Award of Garden Merit.

origin: Mediterranean Europe, Asia, and Africa.
size: squat tree.
growthRate: Rarely exceeds 8–15 meters (25–50 ft) in height.
landscapeUses: Valued for fruit, olive oil production, ornamental.
soilNeeds: Well-drained, fertile soil that is slightly acidic to neutral, with a pH range of 6.5 to 8.5. Can tolerate various soil types from sandy to silty clay loams.
waterNeeds: Drought-tolerant once established. Consistent watering during their first one to two years is crucial. Deep but infrequent watering for established trees.
flowerInfo: Needs a two-month dormancy period with temperatures ideally between 40°F and 50°F to flower.
fruitInfo: Fruit is a drupe, called an "olive." Used for oil, eating (table olives), or both. Harvested from late autumn to early winter.
pruningNeeds: Pruning is best done in late winter or early spring to open the canopy, remove dead or diseased branches, and encourage new fruiting wood.
notes: Among the oldest fruit trees domesticated by humans. Cultivation began between 6,000 and 4,000 BC. Can be grown in containers.

origin: Eastern Asia, ranging from the Himalayas to Japan.
size: Typically grows 4 to 8 feet tall and 2 to 4 feet wide.
texture: Pinnately compound leaves resemble bamboo. Foliage emerges red/bronze
soilNeeds: Ornamental plant.
waterNeeds: Full sun to part shade. Full sun generally leads to the most vibrant foliage color and abundant berry production.
sunsetZone: Well-drained soil that is slightly acidic to neutral (pH 6.0-7.5). Adaptable to various soil types, but thrives in loose, fertile, loamy soil.
usdaZone: Water regularly and deeply during the first growing season. Moderately drought-tolerant once established, requiring water mainly during prolonged dry spells.
fruitInfo: Moderately drought-tolerant.
barkTrunk: Clusters of tiny white flowers bloom in late spring.
rootType: Green berries ripen to bright red and often persist into winter.
plantLocation: Prune in late winter or early spring, before new growth emerges and after the last frost. Thin out a few of the oldest canes at ground level.
image: Native to eastern Asia.

commonName: Capraian cornflower, centaury of Capraia (true species). Velvet Centaurea, Dusty Miller (horticultural commonly known as this, but likely *Centaurea cineraria*).
origin: True species: Capraia, Italy. Horticultural species: Mainland Italy (likely *Centaurea cineraria*).
shape: Herbaceous perennial. Can be used in borders
size: clumps
lightRequirements: Horticultural: Borders, clumps, containers. Adds color contrast with green leafy plants. Provides nectar and pollen for bees and other pollinating insects.
soilNeeds: Horticultural: Full sun exposure and bright, direct sunlight.
waterNeeds: Horticultural: Requires well-drained soil and can even grow in poor, dry conditions. Loamy soil preferred. Resistant to salinity.
sunsetZone: Horticultural: Water sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out almost completely between waterings. Drought-resistant.
flowerInfo: Horticultural: Resistant to salinity and wind. Drought-resistant.
fruitInfo: Horticultural: Yellow or white flowers, generally not decorative and often removed to encourage foliage growth. True species: Flowers attract butterflies and day-flying moths.
plantLocation: Horticultural: Advisable to remove flower buds to encourage more foliage. Intensive pruning every three years can strengthen the plant. Tidy up after flowering.
notes: Horticultural: Generally resistant to pests. Can be susceptible to fungi if there is excessive humidity.
image: True species: Capraia, Italy. Horticultural: Widely cultivated.

origin: Mediterranean region and the Middle East.
shape: Flowering evergreen tree or shrub. Broad hemispherical crown.
size: Can grow up to 15 meters (50 feet) tall.
soilNeeds: 10-20 cm long
waterNeeds: with dark green leaflets.
sunsetZone: Widely cultivated for its edible fruit. Ornamental tree in gardens and landscapes.
tolerances: Drought-resistant. Requires 500-550 millimeters of rainfall annually to produce fruit.
barkTrunk: -7 °C (frost-tolerant)
rootType: Drought-resistant, frost-tolerant.
pruningNeeds: Most carob trees are dioecious (separate male and female plants), though some are hermaphroditic. Male flowers have a distinctive odor.
pestsAndDiseases: Edible fruit (seed pods). Legume, takes a full year to develop and ripen.
notes: Extensive root system with a deep taproot and lateral roots.

origin: Coastal California and northern Baja California, extending into Oregon.
size: dense evergreen shrub. Can be trained into small trees.
growthRate: Typically grows 2–5 meters (6.5–16.5 feet) tall. Older plants can be taller and wider.
soilNeeds: 2–4 cm wide)
waterNeeds: evergreen
sunsetZone: alternate
hardyTo: Cultivated in domestic gardens. Suitable for xeriscape gardening.
flowerInfo: (Not specified)
fruitInfo: (Not specified)
notes: Small, white, mildly fragrant flowers in dense terminal clusters, appear in late spring to early summer. About 6–10 millimeters in diameter with rounded petals.
image: Bright red, pea-sized pomes (berry-like) that mature in the fall and persist into winter. Edible (acidic and astringent), but contains small amounts of cyanogenic glycosides.

origin: First raised in 1886 at the Rovelli nursery in Pallanza (now Verbania), on Lake Maggiore in Italy. Hybrid of *Abelia chinensis* and *Abelia uniflora*.
size: Angiosperms
soilNeeds: Species: A. × grandiflora.
waterNeeds: Deciduous or semi-evergreen multistemmed shrub with rounded
sunsetZone: spreading
hardyTo: 1 to 1.8 m (3.3 to 5.9 ft) tall. Can reach an ultimate height and spread of 2.5–4 meters over 10–20 years.
flowerInfo: Dense
fruitInfo: Leaves are ovate, glossy, dark green.
barkTrunk: Ornamental plant in specimen plantings in gardens, or in a mixed border with other shrubs.
rootType: Full sun. Requires a sheltered position in full sun.
pruningNeeds: Moist, organically rich soils with good drainage.
notes: 6-7 (may die back to ground in 6-7)

origin: US states of Arizona and New Mexico, and to northern Mexico.
size: clump-forming perennial.
growthRate: Basal foliage mound 8-10 inches tall and 12 inches wide. Flowers on slender, leafless stems, typically 12-20 inches tall.
soilNeeds: and can range from glossy green to deep burgundy.
waterNeeds: Attracts bees and hummingbirds.
sunsetZone: Indirect bright light or partial shade. In warmer climates, partial afternoon shade is recommended. In cooler northern climates, it can tolerate full sun.
usdaZone: Well-draining loam soil with a slightly acidic to neutral pH, ideally between 6.0 and 7.0.
hardyTo: Keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water when the soil partially dries out. Drought-tolerant once established but prefers consistently moist conditions.
barkTrunk: Can tolerate some drought once established.
rootType: Showy, sweetly fragrant, bell-shaped flowers that are deep pink to red. Blooming occurs from late spring to early summer (May-July) and can extend through summer to early fall if faded flowers are deadheaded.
plantLocation: Remove spent flower stalks to encourage further blooming. In early spring, trim back any tattered leaves.
notes: Pot-grown Heuchera are particularly susceptible to vine weevil grubs.
image: Primarily found on cliffs, hills, and alpine areas.

origin: Native to tropical and subtropical regions of the Americas and Asia.
density: Large leaves. Exotic or tropical aesthetic in gardens. Water gardens (in arid regions).
waterNeeds: 8b
sunsetZone: -10 °C (14 °F) (USDA Zone 8b).
usdaZone: Implies good tolerance to moisture if grown in water gardens.
hardyTo: (Not detailed, but known as flowering plants)
flowerInfo: Perennial rhizomes.
barkTrunk: (Not specified, but shelter from high winds is advised)
rootType: (Not specified)
pruningNeeds: Tropical and subtropical regions of the Americas and Asia.
pestsAndDiseases: Genus contains 10 species. Often cultivated as annuals in temperate climates. Rhizomes should be dug up before freezing in colder areas.

origin: Cultivar. Collected by Percy Everett in the 1960s, presumed hybrid between *Arctostaphylos nummularia* and *A. uva-ursi*. Named by Lee Lenz and introduced by Saratoga Horticultural Foundation in 1979.
size: dense
density: 10 to 16 inches in height and spreading 3 to 6 feet wide.
soilNeeds: glossy
waterNeeds: deep green leaves. Attractive cinnamon-red stems with exfoliating bark.
sunsetZone: Groundcover, non-walkable lawn substitute.
usdaZone: (Not specified, but generally full sun to light shade for manzanitas)
hardyTo: Rich, slightly acidic, loamy, and well-draining soil.
tolerances: Requires occasional irrigation in Southern California gardens.
fruitInfo: 15-20 degrees Fahrenheit.
barkTrunk: (Not specified)
rootType: Small white flowers appear from mid-winter through spring, somewhat sparse.
pruningNeeds: Red fruit (flowering is somewhat sparse).

origin: Hybrid cross between *C. incana* and *C. mongholica*.
size: deciduous shrub.
growthRate: Typically grows to an average size of 2 to 3 feet tall and wide.
landscapeUses: Grey-green or silvery-gray leaves that are aromatic when bruised.
lightRequirements: Xeriscaping. Attracts butterflies, bees, and other beneficial insects.
soilNeeds: Full sun. Partial shade is acceptable in very hot climates but can reduce compactness.
waterNeeds: Well-draining, sandy or loose loamy soil. Intolerant of wet, poorly-drained soils.
sunsetZone: Can tolerate some drought.
tolerances: Roots are winter hardy to USDA Zone 5. Top growth is only reliably winter hardy to USDA Zone 7.
flowerInfo: Can tolerate some drought.
fruitInfo: Fragrant, bright blue to violet-blue flowers in terminal and axillary clusters. Appear in late summer and early fall. Bloom on new growth.
pestsAndDiseases: Prune back hard in early spring to promote vigorous new growth, as it blooms on new growth.
notes: Unusual in American gardens in the 1960s, more familiar now. Flowers are said to resemble clouds of blue smoke or mist.

commonName: Hardy blue-flowered leadwort, plumbago, leadwort, blue snow-flower
origin: China
size: mat-forming perennial that spreads by rhizomes
density: Typically grows 6-10 inches tall on erect stems. Leaves up to 2 inches long.
lightRequirements: Shiny, medium green leaves, turning bronze-red in autumn.
soilNeeds: Ground cover. Inhibits weed growth.
waterNeeds: (Not specified)
sunsetZone: (Not specified)
fruitInfo: Resistant to deer damage.
barkTrunk: Terminal clusters of 5-petaled, gentian blue flowers, about 1/2 to 3/4 inches in diameter. Appear above the foliage from summer until frost.
pruningNeeds: Rhizomes (spreads by rhizomes).
notes: Native to China.
image: Genus name from Greek words meaning "horn" and "stigma." Specific epithet "plumbaginoides" means "like Plumbago." Flowers resemble those of woodland phlox.

origin: Highlands of Colombia, southern Brazil, northeast Uruguay, eastern Paraguay, and northern Argentina.
size: Typically 1–7 meters (3.3–23.0 ft) tall.
texture: Oblong leaves that are dark green on top and white underneath.
landscapeUses: Widely cultivated as an ornamental tree and for its fruit.
soilNeeds: (Not specified)
waterNeeds: (Not specified)
flowerInfo: Flowers have whitish petals and numerous dark red stamens. Flower petals are edible.
fruitInfo: Fruit (feijoa) matures in autumn, has a green skin. Roughly the size of a chicken egg, sweet, slightly tart, aromatic. Pulp is juicy, with gelatinous seed pulp. Falls to the ground when ripe.
notes: Native to the highlands of Colombia, southern Brazil, northeast Uruguay, eastern Paraguay, and northern Argentina.
image: Also known as *Acca sellowiana*. Fruit prone to bruising and has a relatively short shelf life. Raw feijoa is a rich source of vitamin C. Fruit pulp used in some natural cosmetic products as an exfoliant. Distinctive aroma due to methyl benzoate.

origin: Western and central Mediterranean region.
size: Can grow up to 1 meter (3 feet) tall and 4 meters (13 feet) wide.
soilNeeds: Full sun.
waterNeeds: Neutral or alkaline soil.
sunsetZone: (Not specified)
flowerInfo: Hardy in milder climates.
fruitInfo: Pale blue flowers that bloom in summer.
pruningNeeds: (Not specified)
plantLocation: Native to the western and central Mediterranean region. Prefers a sheltered location.
notes: Latin specific epithet "fruticans" means "shrubby" or "bushy." 'Azureum' received the Royal Horticultural Society's Award of Garden Merit.

commonName: Bay laurel, bay tree, sweet bay, true laurel, Grecian laurel
origin: Mediterranean region
size: Angiosperms
soilNeeds: Species: L. nobilis.
waterNeeds: Aromatic evergreen tree or large shrub. Varies in size
sunsetZone: sometimes reaching 7–18 m (23–59 ft) tall. Dioecious.
usdaZone: 7–18 m (23–59 ft) tall. Can grow up to 20 meters (60 feet) tall.
flowerInfo: Leaves are green
fruitInfo: glabrous (smooth)
barkTrunk: leathery
rootType: thick
pruningNeeds: elliptic to oval
plantLocation: Culinary herb (bay leaf). Ornamental plant in Mediterranean or oceanic climates. House or greenhouse plant in colder regions. Used in topiary for various shapes and low hedges.
notes: Sheltered position in full sun.
image: (Not specified)

commonName: Crape myrtle (crepe myrtle, crêpe myrtle, or crepeflower)
origin: China. Native to subtropical regions of the Himalayas, southern China, mainland Southeast Asia, the Philippines, and Japan.
size: deciduous tree. Wide spreading
texture: or even spike shaped open habit.
landscapeUses: Up to 6 m tall and wide.
waterNeeds: Leaves are small
sunsetZone: smooth-edged
flowerInfo: orange
fruitInfo: and red in autumn. Bark is thin (about 2 mm thick)
barkTrunk: smooth
rootType: pinkish-gray
pruningNeeds: mottled
plantLocation: Widely cultivated as an ornamental plant. Popular nesting shrub for songbirds and wrens.
notes: Full sun. Requires hot summers to flower successfully.
image: Prefers full sun and good drainage.

origin: Himalayas (East-Afghanistan, South Western Tibet, Western Nepal, Northern Pakistan, and North-Central India).
shape: Large evergreen coniferous tree. Conic crown with level branches and drooping branchlets.
size: 40–50 meters (131–164 feet) tall, exceptionally up to 60 meters (197 feet), with a trunk diameter of up to 3 meters (10 feet).
soilNeeds: Urban landscaping. Valued as a building material due to durability and rot-resistant nature.
waterNeeds: (Not specified)
sunsetZone: (Not specified)
fruitInfo: Durable, rot-resistant wood.
barkTrunk: Male cones are 4–6 cm long and shed pollen in autumn.
rootType: Female cones are barrel-shaped, 7–13 cm long, and disintegrate when mature to release winged seeds.
pruningNeeds: (Not specified, but used as a building material)
notes: (Not specified)
image: Himalayas, at altitudes of 1,500–3,200 meters (5,000–10,000 feet).

popularCultivars: Estimated 30 to 35 thousand rose hybrids and cultivars (not listed individually due to scope). Examples of species used for oil: *Rosa × damascena* 'Trigintipetala', *Rosa × centifolia*.
origin: Earliest known cultivation dating back to at least 500 BC in Mediterranean countries, Persia, and China.
classifications: Family: Rosaceae. One of the six most economically important crop plant families.
shape: Deciduous shrub (most common for cultivated roses).
size: Varies greatly
landscapeUses: Ornamental (for aesthetic appeal). Used for rose hips
soilNeeds: hedging.
waterNeeds: (Not specified, but generally full sun for most roses)
sunsetZone: (Not specified, but generally well-drained, fertile soil for most roses)
usdaZone: (Not specified, but generally consistent moisture for most roses)
fruitInfo: Most are double-flowered. Flowers can be various colors.
barkTrunk: Rose hips (ornamental fruit). Rich in vitamin C.
pruningNeeds: (Not specified, but *Rosa multiflora* is used as rootstock)
notes: Widely cultivated globally, especially in temperate climates. Origin in Mediterranean countries, Persia, and China.
image: Estimated 30 to 35 thousand rose hybrids and cultivars. Empress Josephine of France supported rose breeding. Rose oil (attar of roses) produced by steam distillation of petals. Rose water used in cooking, cosmetics, medicine, religious practices.

origin: Cultivated by Aztecs before 1798. Native to Central Mexico, Yucatan, and Guatemala.
lightRequirements: Rich soil with a pH of around 6.5–7.5 and sufficient organic matter.
soilNeeds: Consistent moisture. Thrive in well-watered conditions.
usdaZone: Tubers are hardy to USDA Zone 8 (no frost). In temperate climates with frost, tubers should be dug up and stored.
hardyTo: Can survive a light frost, but colder temperatures will prevent them from thriving.
tolerances: Flowers in almost every color except blue. Bloom from mid-summer through early winter. Over 57,000 registered cultivars.
fruitInfo: Tubers (roots contain inulin).
barkTrunk: Regular deadheading once flowering begins. Taller cultivars often need staking.
pruningNeeds: Native to Central Mexico, Yucatan, and Guatemala. Widely cultivated.
pestsAndDiseases: Roots contain inulin. Tubers have antibiotic compounds. Important root crop and medicinal plant among pre-Columbian Indians.

origin: Western North America (central-southwestern Oregon through most of California and into extreme western Nevada, as well as northern Baja California, Mexico).
shape: Coniferous tree. Young trees have a broad conic crown of spreading branches. Cultivated as an ornamental with a very narrow columnar crown.
size: 30–40 meters (100–130 ft) tall, trunk diameter up to 1.2 meters (3 ft 11 in). Largest known specimen: 47.98 meters (157 ft 5 in) tall.
texture: Foliage consists of flattened sprays with scale-like leaves 2–15 mm long. Bark is initially smooth and orange-brown
lightRequirements: becoming fissured and exfoliates in long strips on older trees.
soilNeeds: Popular ornamental tree. Cultivated in gardens and parks.
waterNeeds: (Not specified)
sunsetZone: (Not specified)
fruitInfo: Fire- and drought-tolerant.
barkTrunk: (Coniferous tree, has cones, not flowers). Male and female cones present.
rootType: Seed cones are 20–35 mm long and contain winged seeds.
pruningNeeds: Bark is initially smooth and orange-brown, weathering to grayish, and on older trees, it becomes fissured and exfoliates in long strips on the lower trunk.
notes: Host for the wood wasp *Syntexis libocedrii* and incense-cedar mistletoe (*Phoradendron libocedri*).
image: Western North America, at altitudes of 50–2,900 m (160–9,510 ft).

origin: Native to the rocky sandstone slopes of the winter rainfall fynbos from the Cape Peninsula to Swellendam in South Africa.
size: Typically 25 to 70 cm in height. Basal, curved, linear leaves up to 60 cm long.
soilNeeds: Cultivated globally, particularly in warm regions. Used in rockeries.
waterNeeds: (Not specified, but needs hot, dry summers and winter rainfall climate)
sunsetZone: Well-drained, slightly acidic sandy soil (for *subsp. africanus*).
usdaZone: Minimal summer watering (for *subsp. walshii*). Adapted to a winter rainfall climate.
fruitInfo: Cannot tolerate extended freezing temperatures.
barkTrunk: Adapted to survive fynbos fires. Cannot tolerate extended freezing temperatures.
rootType: Broadly funnel-shaped, ranging from pale to deep blue, with a dark blue stripe on each petal. Grow in large clusters. Flowers from November to April, with peak flowering from December to February, especially after fires.
pruningNeeds: (Not specified, but seeds dispersed by wind).
notes: fleshy roots.

origin: Western North America, from British Columbia to Oregon and eastern Montana.
size: Up to 3 meters (10 ft) tall and 1.5 meters (5 ft) wide.
landscapeUses: compound pinnate leaves with 7-9 leaflets. Stiff
soilNeeds: spine-tipped along the wavy margin. Lustrous dark green above. May turn bronze to bright red-purple in winter.
sunsetZone: Full sun to partial shade.
barkTrunk: Deer resistant.
rootType: Bright yellow flowers in terminal racemes in early spring.
pruningNeeds: Blue-black, bloomy berries in mid-summer.
image: (Not specified)

popularCultivars: Modern cultivars offer a wide range of colors, sizes, and flowering times. Many cultivated varieties are sterile triploids.
origin: (Not specified, but generally East Asia)
size: Long-lived perennials that form clumps from rhizomes. Arching
growthRate: strap-like leaves grow from the base of the plant in opposite fans.
soilNeeds: strap-like leaves.
waterNeeds: Showy flowers for ornamental purposes.
sunsetZone: Full sun to partial shade. Flowering more prolific in full sun. Pales varieties prefer at least six hours of sun daily. Darker reds and purples might need less.
usdaZone: Adaptable to a range of climatic conditions and most soil types, but prefer well-rained soil that is rich in organic matter with a pH between 6 and 7.
hardyTo: During bloom, require consistently moist soil. Drought-tolerant. Overhead irrigation can mottle or "melt" blooms.
fruitInfo: USDA Zone 4 (for *Hemerocallis fulva*).
barkTrunk: Drought-tolerant. Adaptable to a range of climatic conditions.
rootType: Showy flowers. Each flower typically lasts only a day, but produced in rapid succession for a long blooming period. Wide range of colors.
pestsAndDiseases: Rhizomes (form clumps). Fibrous or fibrous-tuberous root systems that store nutrients and water.
notes: All parts are seriously and often fatally toxic to cats and somewhat toxic to dogs. Cats are particularly vulnerable.

commonName: Society garlic, pink agapanthus, wild garlic, sweet garlic, spring bulbs, spring flowers
origin: Southern Africa (KwaZulu-Natal and the Cape Province). Naturalized in Tanzania and Mexico.
size: clump-forming perennial.
growthRate: Up to 60 cm tall and 25 cm wide.
lightRequirements: Ornamental. Edible leaves and flowers (garlic substitute).
soilNeeds: (Not specified)
waterNeeds: Well-drained soils with mildly acidic, neutral, or mildly alkaline pH.
sunsetZone: Drought-resistant.
flowerInfo: Drought-resistant.
fruitInfo: Fragrant, violet or pinkish-mauve tubular flowers in large clusters on tall stalks. Grouped into umbels (up to 20 flowers per umbel). Blooms from midsummer to autumn.
barkTrunk: Triangular capsules that release flattened, hard black seeds when ripe.
pruningNeeds: (Not specified)
plantLocation: (Not specified, but potential as an antifungal agent).
notes: Indigenous to southern Africa.
image: Leaves emit a strong garlic smell when bruised. Used in traditional medicine. Safety concerns regarding use in high dosages. Leaves and flowers are edible and non-toxic. Species and cultivars received Royal Horticultural Society's Award of Garden Merit.

commonName: Thorny olive, spiny oleaster, silverthorn, Waxleaf Silverberry
origin: Cultivar of *Elaeagnus pungens*, native to Japan.
size: branching evergreen shrub. Low shrub
soilNeeds: and compact.
waterNeeds: 1 to 2 meters in height and spread. (Species can grow up to 7 meters tall and 4 meters wide).
tolerances: elliptic-elongate. Bright golden or deep yellow blotch in the center
flowerInfo: with irregular dark green margins. Undersides are silvery white with brown flecks or clear/translucent spots. Thorns up to 8 cm long.
fruitInfo: Screening, hedging, solitary ornamental plant. Valued for colorful winter foliage. Foliage popular for flower arrangements.
barkTrunk: Sun to light shade. Must be sheltered from winds and winter sun.
rootType: Well-drained, fertile soil.
pruningNeeds: Relatively drought-tolerant.
image: Drought-tolerant. Resistant to salinity and wind.

commonName: Myrtle spurge, blue spurge, broad-leaved glaucous-spurge
origin: Eurasia (Southern Europe and Asia Minor).
size: evergreen perennial flowering plant. Woody base
soilNeeds: blue-green
waterNeeds: fleshy leaves arranged in close spirals.
sunsetZone: Ornamental, used in garden borders, mass plantings, and as a potted plant, particularly in drought-tolerant gardens.
rootType: Drought-tolerant.
pruningNeeds: Inconspicuous greenish flowers subtended by showy yellow bracts. Blooms in spring.

origin: South Africa (drier areas of the southwestern Cape). Naturalized in India, Australia, and New Zealand.
size: suckering shrub.
growthRate: 2–3 meters (7–10 feet) tall and 1–3 meters (3–10 feet) wide.
soilNeeds: which emit a musky odor when touched.
waterNeeds: Cultivated worldwide as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage.
sunsetZone: (Not specified)
barkTrunk: Hardy in milder climates.
rootType: Dark red, nectar-laden flower spikes that are 30–80 cm (12–31 in) in length, produced in spring. Attract birds (sunbirds, white-eyes, red-winged starlings) and bees.
pruningNeeds: Green pods.
image: All parts are poisonous. Leaves are toxic to grazing animals.

commonName: Red yucca, hummingbird yucca, redflower false yucca, samandoque
popularCultivars: (Not specified, but a yellow-flowered variety is available)
origin: Native to the Chihuahuan and Coahuilan deserts of Northern Mexico, as well as Central, Southern, and Western Texas.
shape: Succulent plant that grows in clumps.
size: Clumps reaching heights and widths of up to 3–6 feet (0.91–1.83 meters). Inflorescences can extend up to 5 feet (1.5 meters) in length.
landscapeUses: funnel-like evergreen leaves with slightly sharp tips and a fringe of white
soilNeeds: Popular choice for landscaping due to its drought and heat tolerance. Used in roadside plantings, public areas, and collector gardens. Attracts pollinators, especially hummingbirds.
waterNeeds: (Not specified, but thrives in desert conditions suggesting full sun)
sunsetZone: (Not specified, but implied to be well-drained for desert plants)
fruitInfo: Drought and heat tolerance.
barkTrunk: Vibrant red or yellow tubular flowers on branching, reddish-tinted inflorescences. Appear from late spring to midsummer.
notes: (Not specified)
image: Native to the Chihuahuan and Coahuilan deserts of Northern Mexico, as well as Central, Southern, and Western Texas.

commonName: Burning bush, winged euonymus, winged spindle, winged spindle-tree
origin: Central and northern China, Japan, and Korea.
texture: Branches with unusual "wings" (four brown cork-like protrusions). Leaves are ovate-elliptic
lightRequirements: turn bright red or red-purple in the fall.
soilNeeds: Ornamental plant in gardens and parks due to bright fruit and vibrant autumn color.
waterNeeds: (Not specified)
sunsetZone: (Not specified)
fruitInfo: (Not specified)
barkTrunk: Inconspicuous flowers.
rootType: Oval, sharply pointed, bright red-orange berries encased in a capsule.
pruningNeeds: (Not specified, but branches have "wings")
image: (Not specified)

origin: South America
size: Branches 2 to 8 meters long. Base can exceed 10 centimeters in diameter.
texture: 1-inch long ovate or ovate-lanceolate green leaves.
landscapeUses: Ornamental garden plant. Quickly covers trellises or fences.
soilNeeds: (Not specified)
waterNeeds: (Not specified)
tolerances: Can tolerate temperatures down to 20 degrees Fahrenheit.
flowerInfo: Clusters of small white flowers accented with tiny yellow pistils. Bloom from spring through the end of summer, or even year-round in some climates. Profuse white, star-shaped flowers from summer to fall. More aromatic in the evening.
barkTrunk: Woody
rootType: (Not specified)
pruningNeeds: (Not specified)
plantLocation: Native to South America. Cultivated in warm temperate zones or tropical mountain regions. Introduced in various countries.
notes: Climbs by winding its leaf stalks around supports. In mild winter climates, it remains evergreen.

origin: Mountainous regions of Japan (Shikoku and Kyushu), Taiwan.
shape: Dwarf evergreen shrub or small tree. Fine-textured
size: loose
density: Typically grows to about 1 meter (3.3 feet) tall and wide. Some varieties can mature to 6-8 feet tall with a spread of up to 16 feet wide.
texture: Relatively fast (up to 12 inches per year for some varieties)
soilNeeds: rounded leaves up to 1 inch long. Leaves may turn orange-red-bronze in fall in sun. Branchlets are sharply quadrangular.
waterNeeds: Ornamental, hedging, topiary.
sunsetZone: Part shade preferred (open sun-dappled conditions or light shade with morning/early afternoon sun). Can grow in full shade (less vigorous). Full sun can cause scorching, winter bronzing, or mite attacks.
usdaZone: Moist, well-drained loams with a slightly acidic to slightly alkaline pH.
barkTrunk: Drought-tolerant, resistant to deer, rabbits, and nematodes. Tolerant of pruning and shearing.
rootType: Inconspicuous, apetalous, pale yellow flowers bloom in March. Small, green to cream, 4-parted. Emit a pleasant fragrance.
pruningNeeds: Small, inconspicuous capsules (green, maturing to brownish), about 1/3 inch in diameter. Split into three parts to reveal seeds.
notes: Tolerant of pruning and shearing. Prune after last spring frost.
image: Susceptible to mite attacks in full sun.
